title: Open Label, Single-Arm, Multi-Centre, Study to Validate a New Alzheimer's Disease Scale in Patients With DAT, Treated With Memantine
description_brief: To validate a new Alzheimer's Disease scale against other rating tools in subjects with dementia of Alzheimer's type, treated with memantine.
explanation_target: Reason: The trial description states patients with dementia of Alzheimer’s type (DAT) are being treated with memantine while a new AD scale is validated. Memantine is a small‑molecule, uncompetitive NMDA receptor antagonist used to provide symptomatic benefit (improvements in cognition/global function) in moderate‑to‑severe Alzheimer’s disease rather than a biologic that targets core AD pathology (amyloid or tau). citeturn1search3turn0search1

Act: Key extracted details — intervention: memantine (oral small molecule, marketed as Namenda/Ebixa, etc.); mechanism: NMDA (glutamate) receptor antagonist; intended effect in clinic: symptomatic cognitive/functional improvement in moderate‑to‑severe AD. The trial is open‑label, single‑arm (no placebo) validating a scale in patients receiving memantine, so the study context is observational/scale validation rather than testing a disease‑modifying effect. citeturn1search5turn0search5

Reflect: Classification check — memantine is not a biologic (so not "disease‑targeted biologic") and it does not primarily target amyloid or tau pathology (so not "disease‑targeted small molecule"). Its approved/typical use is symptomatic cognitive/functional improvement, matching the "cognitive enhancer" category. The trial description (scale validation in patients treated with memantine) fits this category; note the trial itself is not an efficacy RCT but a validation study conducted in patients receiving a symptomatic cognitive treatment. citeturn0search0turn0search6
